facts.text: The respondent is a company registered under the Indian Companies Act, 1913, carrying on business in cotton.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent is a companypany registered under the Indian Companies Act, 1913, and is carrying on business in companyton.

facts.text: Head office of respondent is in Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: Its head office is in BOmbay, and it maintains a branch at Karachi of purchasing companyton for

facts.text: Respondent maintains a branch at Karachi for purchasing cotton for shipment to Bombay or export.

anchor.surface_text: Its head office is in BOmbay, and it maintains a branch at Karachi of purchasing companyton for shipment to Bombay or export direct to other places.

facts.text: Separate accounts are maintained and separate profit and loss statements prepared for Bombay and Karachi.

anchor.surface_text: Separate accents are maintained and separate profit and loss statements are prepared for the business at Bombay and at Karachi.

facts.text: Agreement dated 22nd December with managing agents, clause 4 fixes remuneration at 20% of net annual profits.

anchor.surface_text: BY an agreement dated 22nd December Ltd., as its managing agents, and under clause 4 of the agreement, the remuneration payable to them was fixed at 20 per cent. Of the net annul profits.

facts.text: Accounting year 1st October 1947 to 30th September 1948.

anchor.surface_text: During the accounting year 1st October, 1947, to 30th September, 1948, the respondent made a total profit of Rs. 15,63,504,

facts.text: Total profit Rs. 15,63,504, of which Rs. 9,44,905 in Bombay and Rs. 6,18,599 at Karachi.

anchor.surface_text: the respondent made a total profit of Rs. 15,63,504, of which Rs. 9,44,905 was earned in the business at Bombay and Rs. 6,18,599 at Karachi.

facts.text: Commission payable to managing agents Rs. 3,12,699 as per clause 4.

anchor.surface_text: On this, the companymission payable to the managing agents as per clause 4 of the agreement was Rs. 3,12,699.

facts.text: Respondent debited Rs. 1,88,980 to Bombay profit and loss, showing net Rs. 7,55,925.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent debited a sum of Rs. 1,88,980 out of this amount in the profit and loss statement of the Bombay head office, being the 20 apportionable to the profits shown there in, and deducting this sum of the total profits of Rs. 9,44,905 showed a sum of Rs. 7,55,925 as the net profits of the business of Bombay.

facts.text: Respondent debited Rs. 1,23,719 to Karachi profit and loss, showing net Rs. 4,94,879.

anchor.surface_text: It likewise debited a sum of Rs. 1,23,719 to the profit and a loss statement of the Karachi branch, and deducting it out of the total profits of Rs. 6,18,599 earned by the branch, showed a sum of Rs. 4,94,879 as its net profits.

facts.text: Respondent is resident and ordinarily resident in India.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent is resident and ordinarily resident in India,. and therefore it would be chargeable to in companye tax its total world income.

facts.text: Income Tax Officer determined total income at Rs. 13,09,375 after deducting entire commission.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, the Income tax office took into the account profits earned both in India nd in Karachi deducted therefrom the entire companymission paid to the managing agents, and after making certain adjustment, which are number material for the present purpose, determined the total income at Rs. 13,09,375.

facts.text: Correctness of total income figure Rs. 13,09,375 not in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: The companyrectness of this figure is number number in dispute.

facts.text: Notification issued on 10th December 1947 for avoidance of double taxation with Pakistan.

anchor.surface_text: section 49 b , provided that the Central Government may enter into an agreement with Pakistan for the avoidance of double taxation of income, profits and gains under this Act. And in exercise of the powers companyferred under this sectarian. a numberification was issued on the 10th December, 1947.,

facts.text: ITO accepted Rs. 4,94,879 as net profits of Karachi for relief calculation, after adjustments Rs. 5,00,344.

anchor.surface_text: For this purpose, he accepted as c companyrect the sum of Rs. 4,94,879 which the respondent had shown as the net profits in the profits and loss statement for karachi, and after making certain adjustment and deductions in accordance with clause 4 of the agreement and item 7  a  in the schedule annexed thereto, held that the amount in respect of which the respondent was entitled to abatement under the agreement was Rs. 5,00344.

facts.text: Assessee appealed to Appellate Assistant Commissioner contending ITO erred in taking Rs. 4,94,879 instead of Rs. 6,18,599 for Karachi profits.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee preferred to an appeal against this order to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, and companytended that the Income Tax Officer was in error in taking Rs. 4,94,879 given in the profits and loss statement for Karachi as the profits of the Karachi branch, because this figure had been arrived at after the deducting a sum of Rs. 1,23,719 being the proportionate of the amount of the managing agency companymission but that the whole of it was payable at Bombay and was debatable to the head office, and that accordingly, the sum of Rs, 6,18,599 should have been taken as the profits of the branch and number Rs. 4,94,879.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner confirmed ITO order.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner disagreed with this companytention, a nd companyfirmed the order of the Income Tax offer.

facts.text: Tribunal held entire commission payable at Bombay, no portion to Karachi branch, allowed appeal to that extent.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent took the matter in appeal to the Tribunal, which held that the terms of the managing agency agreement, the entire companymission was payable at bombay, and that the accordingly numberportion of it should be debited to the Karachi branch. In the result the appeal was to that the extent allowed.

facts.text: On application of Commissioner, Tribunal referred question to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon, on the application of the Commissioner, the Tribunal referred the following question for the decision of the High Court.

facts.text: Referred question: Whether Rs. 1,23,719 paid as commission on Karachi profits allowable as deduction against Indian profits.

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the fact and in the circumstance of the case, the amount of Rs. 1,23,719 paid to the managing agents as companymission at 20 of the net profits of the Karachi branch, is allowable as a revenue deduction against the Indian profits of the assess companypany for the year of account ?

facts.text: High Court (Chagla CJ and Tendolkar J) answered reference in affirmative, following Birla Brothers Ltd. v. CIT.

anchor.surface_text: This reference was heard by Chagla, C.J. and Tendolkar, J. ... But they held following the decision in Birla Brothers Ltd. V. Commissioner of Income tax the hanging agency companymission should in its entirely be debited to the BOMBAY branch, ... and accordingly answered the reference in the affirmative.

facts.text: High Court granted certificate under section 66A for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: They, however, granted a certificate under section 66-A of the income TAx Act to appeal to this companyrt.

facts.text: Solicitor General for appellant contended Rs. 1,23,719 should be added back for Pakistan profits as relief already given twice.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the Appellate, the learned Solicitor General companytended that the sum of Rs. 1,23,719 companyld number to be added to the sum of Rs. 4,94,879 as the profits assessable to income tax in Pakistan, because the entire companymission of Rs, 3,12,699 due under the agreement had been deducted out of the Rs. 15,63,504 the total income of the assessee,

facts.text: Mr. Kolah for respondent contended deduction of Rs. 1,23,719 in Karachi was mistake, Pakistan later disallowed it.

anchor.surface_text: Forth respondent, Mr. Kolah companytended that under the provision of the Income TAx Act the respondent was number entitled to deduct Rs. 1,23,719, in the profits earned at Karachi, that in deducting that amount in the profits and loss statement for karachi the assessee had made mistake, and that, in fact, the Income Tax authorities in Pakistan who had originally admitted the deduction on the basis of the profits and loss statement had subsequently revised the assessment on the ground of error, and the had disallowed it.

facts.text: Supreme Court held respondent entitled to deduct entire commission including Rs. 1,23,719 against Indian profits as one business.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent is therefore clearly entitled to the managing agents including the sum of Rs. 1,23,719 against the Indian profits.

facts.text: Apportionment of commission not warranted by managing agency agreement.

anchor.surface_text: It should further be added that the apportionment of the Rs. 1,23,719 in the profit and loss statement of the on Which the appellant rests his argument is number warranted by the terms of the managing agency agreement, and is indeed opposed to them.
